description: A very soft flue stop of 8' or 4' pitch, made in a variety of forms, including wood, metal, open, and stopped. Audsley calls it the softest flute tone in the organ, essentially the same as the Echoflöte. The name means �distant flute�. The name Fern Flute does not appear in the literature; we assume it to be a synonym. Other stops which claim to be the softest are Dolcissimo, Echo Dulciana Celeste, Echo Gamba, Viola d'Amore, Vox Angelica, and Vox Mystica.
examplesDescription: Osiris contains two dozen examples, roughly half at 8' pitch and half at 4'. The earliest are listed below.

examples.name: Fern Flöte 4', Nebenwerk; Dom, Fulda, Germany; Sauer 1874-77. Rebuilt in 1996 by Rieger, this stop is now in the Oberwerk.
Fern Flute 8', Echo; Congregational Church, Great Barrington, Massachusetts, USA; Roosevelt 1883.

Fern Flute 8', Choir; Church of St. Mary, Tyne Dock, England; Schulze. Audsley describes this example as an extremely soft Spitzflöte, Wedgwood calls it a delicate Gemshorn, and according to Bonavia-Hunt it is almost exactly the same as Schulze's Zartflöte.
